Award.AwardTitle: Establishing LINK2SUCCESS at Texas Southmost College

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project was submitted in response to the Dear Colleague Letter for Hispanic Serving Institutions "Stimulating Research on Effective Strategies in Undergraduate STEM Education at Two-Year Hispanic Serving Institutions," NSF15-078. It will provide course enrichment and mentoring support to students at the Texas Southernmost College (TSC), a Hispanic Serving community college located in the vicinity of the University of Texas at Brownsville and the University of Texas Pan American. (These two universities have recently been merged into a single institution -- University of Texas Rio Grande Valley.) STEM graduates from TSC who decide to work on a bachelor's degree typically choose to attend UT Rio Grande Valley campuses and UT Grande Valley is committed to student success at TSC. The project is adopting an approach used successfully at UT Brownsville, called "Link2Success" (L2S). The L2S approach provides STEM instructors with highly trained and certified student course assistants, drawing them from the ranks of advanced STEM students at UT Brownsville. These assistants are assigned to work with course instructors by leading small mandatory discussion sections. The project is transforming 10 introductory gatekeeper courses in mathematics, biology, chemistry, and physics. The L2S assistants not only lead discussion groups, they also assist the students for whom they are responsible to successfully transition to college life by being peer and academic role models. The L2S model provides first-year students taking STEM courses with regular contact with individuals like themselves, an approach that is known in general to be effective.

The project will measure the impact on student success in completing gatekeeper courses and continuing to take additional STEM courses. Credible measurement methods will be used to isolate the net impact of the L2S course assistants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Link2Success (L2S) academic support model was successful in contributing to a positive gain in student academic achievement in College Algebra and Anatomy and Physiology I & II for community college students. The major goals were to (1) implement the L2S program on a community college campus employing 20+ university student employees and providing academic support to approximately 400 students in STEM courses; (2) seek constant improvement based on data that was collected; (3) contribute to an increase in overall course pass rates in select STEM courses; and (4) Train TSC students to be L2S leaders to ensure sustainability. Significant gains were seen in the Sense of Classroom Community Index (SCCI) as well as the average final grades in College Algebra as well as Anatomy & Physiology I & II and the focus group responses were positive as well.

One of the major goals of this project was to contribute to an increase in pass rates, decrease in withdrawal rates, and an increase in retention rates. Rovai (2002) cites Brufee 1993; Dede, 1996; and Wellman, 1999 in stating “Research provides evidence that strong feelings of community may not only increase persistence in courses, but may also increase the flow of information among all learners, availability of support, commitment to group goals, cooperation among members, and satisfaction with group efforts (p. 3). According to Rovai (2002), definitions of community (McMillan and Chavis, 1986; Westheimer and Kahne, 1993; and Graves, 1992) “one can expect that members of classroom communities will have feelings of belonging and trust. They will believe that they matter to one another and to the group; that they have duties and obligations to each other and to the school; and that they possess a shared faith that members’ educational needs will be met through their commitment to shared goals. Accordingly, classroom community can be constitutively defined in terms of four dimensions: spirit, trust, interaction, and commonality of expectations and goals, in this case, learning” (Rovai, 2002, pg. 4).A pre and post-test of a classroom community measure was administered and resulted in significant gains in each of the four subscales of Spirit, Trust, Interaction, and Learning.

In alignment with the goals of the project, average final course grades were compared between students who participated in L2S course sections versus those of students not enrolled in and participating in L2S course sections. Significant gains were found in College Algebra as well as Anatomy and Physiology I & II with students participating in L2S outperforming students not participating in L2S. With data collection difficulties between the two different institutions and taking into consideration sample size and consistency of data collected, Spring 2017 average final course grades were analyzed. There was a significant difference between the average final course grades of L2S students (77.80) and non-L2S students (73.64) in College Algebra. In Anatomy and Physiology I the difference between average final course grades of L2S students and non-L2S students was 87.54 and 78.87 respectively. Finally, the difference between the average final course grades of L2S and non-L2S students in Anatomy and Physiology II was 89.15 and 76.72 respectively.

Through focus groups, students and L2S leaders (student employees) both expressed a positive experience with the L2S program. Students and student leaders both agreed that the L2S program was very helpful. They revealed that they have grown, become active learners, and have studied and learned better. From students, the advantages and benefits of L2S included: make grades better, complete homework assignments with assistance, better understand the subjects and materials, have more opportunities to learn outside the classroom, reinforce the materials they have learned, obtain better grades, and get fresher and deeper memories in mind. From student leaders, the advantages and benefits of L2S included: review materials, help with current study and future careers, get deeper learning of the materials, and help students to be better, more independent, and more successful students.
